job_title: Clinical Therapist II in Hampton, VA
pros: The clinical team is kind, supportive, and very friendly.
cons: Micromanaged, too much administrative work, limited opportunities for growth in the organization

pros: As an licensed employee, you received $500 for continuing education every year and you can complete your trainings during your work hours. Management has been making positive changes to assist with completing documentation. We are currently allow one hour daily to get reports completed. My supervisor and program supervisor are open to suggestions regarding making it a better work environment for everyone.
cons: As always, there are cons to working anywhere. You usually carry a case load of 80 to 85 clients. Most of the time you aren’t seeing them on a weekly or no-weekly bases. Some you haven’t seen for a couple of months but they have to stay on your case load for 130 days per Department of Behavioral Health requirements and you have to contact them once a month until 100 days have occurred. Clients are allowed to continue to miss up to 2 sessions before being required to work with an Engagement Specialist. If they miss two additional sessions in a row then you can discharge them. If they show to one appointment and not the other you continue to see them. Once they have attended the two appointments they no longer work with an engagement specialist and won’t be put back on the list again until they miss another two appointments . You get clients who know these rules and continue to miss one appointment after another. If you aren’t use to doing 90 day reports and annual assessments, this can be a lot to handle. As any community-based program it’s a lot of paperwork involved.

pros: Safe, helpful team, sometimes free training
cons: productivity is priority over taking care of clients

review_title: HNNCSB - Employer of Choice in the Hampton Roads area of Virginia
pros:
Hampton-Newport News Community Services Board provides the following to their employees and the clients they serve:
1.  Being a premier provider of mental health services in so many different aspects.  This helps the employees feel proud of what they do and how it improves the lives of the clients we serve.
2.  Finding ways to make employees feel valued -- most recent example:  the implementation of eLearning so ALL employees can improve their professional/clinical skills at no cost.
3.  Good communication -- a dedicated website for all CSB employees; open lines of communication between all levels of management and line staff.
cons: I have worked at HNNCSB for over 6 months now.  I honestly can state that I don't see any serious downside to working for this organization.  Like any organization in these economic times, budgetary concerns impact employees from time to time but does not compromise care to our clients.  The only downside may be the number of programs and employees keeps us from knowing each other as much as we would like.  But even then, there are employee functions/events to bring us all together such as the 4th of July picnic.

pros: Decent benefits package, some departments are better than others.
cons: Politics, politics, politics!  Senior management is out of touch, it is generally a good old boys/girls network.  Middle management/supervisors tend to be the ones that have been there decades, whether they are qualiied to lead or not.  They continue doing things the way they have always done it, whether it is destructive or violates state policy until they are caught by the state.  If someone on the lower level brings violations or better ways to do someting to their attention, they either ignore it or put a target on that person's back.

review_title: Only cares about how things look - don't care about people who live here or work here.
job_title: Community Service Associate in Hampton, VA
pros:
has very good insurance, training and other perks such as gym memberships at reduced rates
has better pay than other companies who provide services to the disabled
cons:
I've been working here for about 4 years.  The company used to care about the individuals who lived here - making sure that their rights were protected and that person centered options were used.  Now, we are told "they don't really know what their rights are so just do what I told you to do."  Individuals are no longer able to decorate their bedrooms as they like it.  The new supervisor has thrown out a lot of personal items which made the individuals upset (understandably!!).  And when those that had family asked about it, she stated "Oh, I don't know what havppened - staff must have accidently thrown it out!!"  It's very frustrating.  Also, new supervisor is trying to get rid of those individuals who might be "trouble" such those who have mobility problems and those with behavioral issues (which have increased drastically since she started because she makes them do things they don't want to do such as go on outings).  Also, the company has started transferring staff who have been at residences for a long time and sending them to a new house saying that they don't want the employees to get "too comfortable."  However, they do not take into consideration that the people who live in these houses sometimes have no family involvement and look at staff as their family.  Moving staff is causing a lot of problems in the homes.  HNNCSB also doesn't care how these moves are afftecting staff.  They are making staff take positions that interfer with other aspects of life.  For example, making a staff person who had a Sun - Wed morning shift position and moving them to a Wed - Sat evening shift position and not caring that this person has a second job.  HNNCSB is not flexible - their position is "too bad, if you don't like it, you can leave."
So my advice - if all you care about is pay and benefits, then HNNCSB is your place to work.  But if you actually care about the people you service, than stay clear!

pros: In the beginning it was great. I really enjoyed getting days off when the schools are closed and being paid for that time. Coworkers were also helpful and down to earth.
cons: Some coworkers have a lot of mental issues themselves which can make work stressful. Or they don't pull their own weight. Management can change at anytime and they all have different management styles. My first manager was more authoritarian. She was more like a bully. My current supervisor is more relaxed but offers very little guidance.

review_title: Not a horrible place to work
job_title: Certified Peer Recovery Specialist in Newport News, VA
pros: Work life balance, annual and sick leave, staff development. Very approachable supervisor
cons: Worked a pilot program that didn't have a lot of structure. Lack of communication on a regular basis, often I had no idea what my teammates were doing. They offer leave monthly, but don't like it if you actually use it. At least that was my experience when I failed to let HR know I needed FMLA when I was having mental health issues. I could have appealed my termination, but I was looking to move on from the agency anyways.
